title: Hemorrhoids with Prolapsing Internal Piles
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman complains of bleeding during bowel movements and prolapse that she manually reduces. She has tried dietary modifications and topical treatments without relief. No weight loss or family history of colon cancer.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Obtain history of bleeding, prolapse, pain, and risk factors such as constipation, pregnancy, or liver disease.
Perform anorectal examination with visual inspection, digital rectal exam, and anoscopy confirming grade III internal hemorrhoids.
Rule out other causes of bleeding (anal fissure, malignancy) by colonoscopy if patient meets screening criteria.
Discuss conservative measures: high-fiber diet, increased fluids, stool softeners, and topical therapy.
Since conservative measures failed, discuss office procedures (rubber band ligation, infrared coagulation) versus surgical hemorrhoidectomy.
Explain indications for excisional hemorrhoidectomy (grade III-IV, large external component, thrombosis).
Obtain informed consent detailing postoperative pain, urinary retention, and risk of stenosis or incontinence.
Perform closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy under regional or general anesthesia; preserve anoderm and avoid sphincter injury.
Manage postoperative pain with multimodal analgesia; prescribe stool softeners and warm sitz baths.
Advise on wound care and hygiene; schedule follow-up to assess healing and complications.
Educate patient on prevention strategies including fiber supplementation and avoiding straining.
Monitor for complications such as bleeding, infection, or anal stenosis and intervene if necessary.

critical_decision_points: Correct diagnosis and grading of hemorrhoids.
Appropriate selection of conservative versus surgical treatment.
Technique of hemorrhoidectomy to avoid sphincter injury and stenosis.
Postoperative pain management and wound care.
Counseling on prevention and recognition of complications.
